diagnoses.name: Kawasaki Disease
diagnoses.description: A condition that causes inflammation in the walls of some blood vessels in the body. It's predominantly seen in children. The symptoms you've described are characteristic of this disease.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can affect any part of the body, including the skin, joints, and organs. Lip and hand erythema, fever, and anemia are common findings.

diagnoses.name: Infectious Mononucleosis
diagnoses.description: Often called mono or the 'kissing disease,' it's an infection typically caused by the Epstein-Barr virus. Symptoms include fever, sore throat, swollen lymph nodes, and potentially swollen liver or spleen.

diagnoses.name: Scarlet Fever
diagnoses.description: A bacterial illness that develops in some people who have strep throat. It features a bright red rash that covers most of the body, sore throat, fever, and swollen lymph nodes.

diagnoses.name: Drug Hypersensitivity Reaction
diagnoses.description: An immune system reaction to a particular drug. Symptoms can include fever, rash (erythema of the hands and lips could be part of this rash), swollen lymph nodes, and anemia.

diagnoses.name: Stevens-Johnson Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare, serious disorder of your skin and mucous membranes. It's usually a reaction to a medication or an infection. Fever, sore mouth and throat, and fatigue are typical symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatic Fever
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that can develop as a complication of inadequately treated strep throat or scarlet fever. Symptoms include fever, painful and tender joints, rash, and nodules near the skin's surface.

diagnoses.name: Toxic Shock Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare, life-threatening complication of certain types of bacterial infections. Often associated with tampon use but can occur with skin wounds and surgery. Symptoms include fever, rash, and low blood pressure.

diagnoses.name: Erythema Multiforme
diagnoses.description: An acute, sometimes recurrent, skin condition considered to be a hypersensitivity reaction associated with certain infections, medications, and other various triggers.

diagnoses.name: Measles
diagnoses.description: A highly contagious viral infection causing fever, cough, conjunctivitis, and a spreading skin rash. Measles can cause severe health complications, including pneumonia and encephalitis.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: An infectious disease caused by the Borrelia bacterium which is spread by ticks. It can lead to a wide range of symptoms including rash, fever, headaches, and fatigue. Some patients can develop Lyme arthritis, characterized by episodes of swelling and pain in one or more joints.

diagnoses.name: Psoriatic Arthritis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory arthritis associated with psoriasis, characterized by joint pain and swelling. Psoriatic rash can vary in appearance, including annular or ring-shaped patterns.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatic Fever
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that can develop as a complication of inadequately treated strep throat or scarlet fever. Symptoms can include arthritis, fever, and rash. It can cause long-term complications in the heart, joints, skin, and brain.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can affect various parts of the body, including the skin, joints, kidneys, blood cells, brain, heart, and lungs. Symptoms can vary but often include fatigue, joint pain, rash, and fever.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease marked by muscle weakness and a distinctive skin rash. Symptoms may include a heliotrope rash on the eyelids and a rash on the knuckles, elbows, knees, chest, and back.

diagnoses.name: Leptospirosis
diagnoses.description: A bacterial disease that affects humans and animals. It is caused by bacteria of the genus Leptospira. Symptoms can range from none to severe and can include high fever, headache, chills, muscle aches, vomiting, jaundice, red eyes, abdominal pain, diarrhea, and rash.

diagnoses.name: Hepatitis B
diagnoses.description: A viral infection that attacks the liver and can cause both acute and chronic disease. Symptoms include yellowing of the eyes (jaundice), abdominal pain, and dark urine. Chronic cases can lead to liver cirrhosis or liver cancer.

diagnoses.name: Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever
diagnoses.description: A bacterial infection transmitted by ticks. Symptoms include fever, headache, rash, and vomiting. It can be serious or fatal if not treated in the first few days of symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Secondary Syphilis
diagnoses.description: A stage of syphilis that occurs approximately four to ten weeks after the primary infection. While secondary syphilis can be asymptomatic, it often presents with a rash that can appear on the palms of the hands and soles of the feet.

diagnoses.name: Henoch-Schönlein Purpura
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the blood vessels that can cause rash, abdominal pain, and arthritis. It is most commonly seen in children but can affect people of any age.

diagnoses: Hepatitis B or C with cryoglobulinemia
Hepatitis B or C with renal involvement
Chronic Kidney Disease secondary to Glomerulonephritis
Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) / Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome (AIDS)
Vitamin deficiency (e.g., Vitamin B12, Vitamin C deficiency)
Inflammatory bowel disease (e.g., Crohn's disease, ulcerative colitis)
Neurological disorders (e.g., multiple sclerosis, Parkinson's disease)

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.name: Allergic reaction
diagnoses.description: An immune system response to a foreign substance that's not typically harmful to your body. These foreign substances are called allergens. They can include certain foods, pollen, or pet dander. Your immune system’s job is to keep you healthy by fighting harmful pathogens. It does this by attacking anything it thinks could put your body in danger. This response can cause an allergic reaction, which can lead to symptoms such as sinus inflammation (sinusitis), rashes, and angioedema.

diagnoses.name: Serum sickness
diagnoses.description: A reaction that's similar to an allergy. This condition happens when the immune system goes into attack mode against a medication or therapy that contains antiserum or antitoxin. It can result in rashes, fever (hyperthermia), and joint pain, which may relate to hypermobility.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Angioedema
diagnoses.description: A rare, genetic disorder characterized by severe, recurring attacks of swelling. The symptoms can affect various body parts including the hands, feet, face, intestinal wall, and airways. It can be associated with skin rashes and tends to occur in people with a family history of the condition. Patients often report a higher degree of joint hypermobility.

diagnoses.name: Drug reaction
diagnoses.description: Adverse reactions to a drug can manifest in various ways, including rashes, hyperthermia, angioedema, and more. Some drug reactions can also result in symptoms that mimic sinusitis due to fluid retention or allergic responses.

diagnoses.name: Mast Cell Activation Syndrome (MCAS)
diagnoses.description: A condition in which mast cells behave abnormally and excessively release chemicals that can lead to a wide range of chronic symptoms. This can include skin rashes, sinusitis, hypotension, and sometimes higher body temperatures or hypermobility issues.

diagnoses.name: Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease in which the immune system attacks its own tissues, causing widespread inflammation and tissue damage in the affected organs. It can cause rashes, fever (hyperthermia), and joint pain/hypermobility.

diagnoses.name: Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (EDS)
diagnoses.description: A group of disorders that affect the connective tissues supporting the skin, bones, blood vessels, and many other organs and tissues. It's known for causing hypermobility, and patients may report associated symptoms such as rashes due to skin fragility.

diagnoses.name: Anaphylaxis
diagnoses.description: A severe, potentially life-threatening allergic reaction that can occur rapidly. It can cause angioedema, rash, and a sudden drop in blood pressure. While sinusitis and hyperthermia are not classic symptoms, the body’s extreme allergic response can trigger a wide array of symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Infectious mononucleosis
diagnoses.description: A viral infection caused by the Epstein-Barr virus. Symptoms can include fever (hyperthermia), rash, and sore throat, which can sometimes be confused with sinusitis. Some reports suggest joint pain and fatigue, which may be linked to hypermobility or physical stress on the body.

diagnoses.name: Stevens-Johnson Syndrome / Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis
diagnoses.description: A rare, serious disorder of the skin and mucous membranes. It's usually a reaction to a medication or an infection. Symptoms begin with flu-like symptoms, followed by a painful red or purplish rash that spreads and blisters, eventually causing the top layer of the skin to die and shed.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses: Vitamin B12 or folate deficiency anemia
Urinary Tract Infection (as a cause of incontinence)
Asthma exacerbation due to an allergic reaction
Urticaria (Hives) due to an allergic reaction
Anisakiasis (due to ingestion of raw fish)
Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE) with anaphylactoid reaction
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (Crohn's Disease, Ulcerative Colitis)
Allergic reaction to food or medication

diagnoses.name: Migraine with aura
diagnoses.description: A type of headache characterized by recurrent attacks of moderate to severe pain, often accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light or sound. Aura symptoms can include visual disturbances (scintillations) and speech disturbances (aphasia).

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A medical condition that occurs when the blood supply to part of the brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Symptoms can include headache, trouble speaking or understanding speech (aphasia), and visual disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Transient ischemic attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a 'mini-stroke,' a transient ischemic attack is a temporary period of symptoms similar to those of a stroke. A TIA usually lasts only a few minutes and doesn't cause permanent damage. Symptoms can include headache, aphasia, and visual problems.

diagnoses.name: Brain tumor
diagnoses.description: An abnormal growth of cells within the brain, which can be cancerous or benign. Symptoms can include new onset or change in pattern of headaches, vomiting, vision problems (like scintillations), and speech difficulties (including aphasia).

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the protective membranes covering the brain and spinal cord, usually due to infection. Symptoms can include headache, vomiting, fever, confusion, and in severe cases, disturbances in vision and speech.

diagnoses.name: Subarachnoid hemorrhage
diagnoses.description: Bleeding in the space between the brain and the tissue covering the brain. It is often signaled by a sudden, severe headache, and can also lead to vomiting, seizures, visual issues, and speech disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Epilepsy
diagnoses.description: A neurological disorder marked by sudden recurrent episodes of sensory disturbance, loss of consciousness, or convulsions, associated with abnormal electrical activity in the brain. Specific types of epilepsy may include visual disturbances and speech difficulties as aura symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Intracerebral hemorrhage
diagnoses.description: Bleeding within the brain tissue itself, which can lead to symptoms such as severe headache, vomiting, seizures, visual disturbances, and difficulty with speech including aphasia.

diagnoses.name: Hypertensive encephalopathy
diagnoses.description: A syndrome resulting from acutely elevated blood pressure. It can lead to symptoms such as headache, vomiting, visual disturbances, altered mental status, and seizures.

diagnoses.name: Multiple sclerosis (MS)
diagnoses.description: A potentially disabling disease of the brain and spinal cord (central nervous system). While symptoms can vary widely, they may include fatigue, dizziness, muscle weakness, vision problems, and difficulty with coordination and speech.

diagnoses: Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA, formerly Wegener's granulomatosis)

Rheumatoid Arthritis with secondary Sjögren's syndrome
